author: alexandair
body:
PowerShell Core on Linux.

Steps to reproduce
------------------
```
# this works
Remove-Module psreadline
# this fails
Import-Module psreadline
# you need to run
Import-Module PSReadLine 
```
Expected behavior
-----------------
Consistent behavior for both cmdlets.

Actual behavior
---------------
```
# this works
Remove-Module psreadline
# this fails
Import-Module psreadline
```
Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
PS /home/aleksandar> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value

```

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
@alexandair Thanks for your report!

I believe if on Unix we allow import different modules `modulename` and `Modulename` we should be case-sensitive in `Remove-Module` and `Get-Module` too?

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body: Is it a good idea to allow case-sensitive module names considering that Windows will not support such module names as its file system is case-insensitive?  Seems like PowerShell should treat modules as case-insensitive.  I don't see any value in allowing posh-git, Posh-Git and Posh-GIT to be different modules.  I think that would just lead to confusion.  IMO all of the module-related commands should be case-insensitive.  And if on Linux someone has both mymodule and MyModule dirs. and is trying to import Mymodule, PowerShell should warn the user about the conflict.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: If we consider the module names as case-insensitive, then should we do the same in relation to the names of scripts and other PowerShell files?

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body: I don't think so.  Script filename casing should following the OS's casing rules.  That said, the PowerShell Gallery should consider warning (or rejecting) when publishing scripts that would stomp a different script with the same name on a case-insensitive file system.  Either that or use some other means of disambiguation (author name, pub-date, version, etc).

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: I expect that this will amaze users that .psm1 is case-insensitive and .ps1 case-sensitive.

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body: Loading a module by path doesn't have to follow the same rules as loading a module by name.  Considering module "names" are backed by file system names, I'll admit this gets messy.  But given that command names in PowerShell are case-insensitive, it seems like the right way to go.

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body: I believe this is an application of the question raised in #706. Ideally, we should address this all up.

title: Remove-Module doesn't care about casing, but Import-Module does care
